Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Genomic Nature of Adaptation in Anolis lizards
Award.AbstractNarration:
Most of the biological diversity on Earth is thought to result from adaptive radiation, an evolutionary phenomenon where many new species are rapidly formed through colonization of and adaptation to new environments. The work of many researchers over the last fifty years has resulted in an emerging understanding of the broad-scale evolutionary patterns associated with adaptive radiation. Despite these advances, we have little understanding of the genetic processes that take place during adaptive radiation. For instance, it is not known how often new mutations are uniquely favored in one environment alone versus being beneficial to multiple species living in different habitats. This proposal addresses this gap in our knowledge using one of the most iconic examples of adaptive radiation, Anolis lizards from the West Indies. This research will focus on two Anolis species that reside on tree trunks?one living in a hot, dry environment, the other in a moist, cool forest. In a small area of the Dominican Republic, these different habitats are immediately adjacent to one another. Here, the two species interbreed and form hybrid offspring. These unique circumstances provide an opportunity to identify what gene variants are associated with adaptation to the two distinct environments and what variants are beneficial to both species.

To address the genomic nature of adaptation in Anolis lizards, the co-investigators will use next-generation sequencing technologies to collect transcriptome data from individuals of each species as well as hybrids. The genotypes derived from this sequencing will be used to perform genomic cline analyses, which identify parental alleles that are over- and underrepresented among hybrids. The results of genomic cline analyses will be combined with population genomic analyses to identify the frequency of global and local adaptations and provide a first insight into the microevolutionary processes associated with adaptive radiation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the study of two lizard populations from the West Indies. One of these populations has long occupied a hot, dry, desert-like environment. In the last few million years, the second population split off from the first and adapted to a wetter, forested environment. Our group has previously found that natural selection has led this wet habitat population to evolve a number of traits that make it better adapted to this new environment. These two populations live in adjacent areas and sometimes members of each population interbreed. This allows for genes to move between the two groups. The genetic changes that are beneficial to the wet habitat population may not be beneficial to the dry habitat population. If this is the case, we expect natural selection to oppose the movement of these genes, but if changes are beneficial or have to effect on the dry population, they should be able to move freely between populations.

In this project, we tested for three things: 1) genes involved in adaptation in each population and 2) genes that have moved between populations and 3) the overlap between these to groups of genes.
To accomplish these goals we performed 1) fieldwork to gather samples, 2) laboratory work to determine which samples were most useful for study, 3) DNA sequencing to determine the sequence of the majority of genes active in each animal, and 4) statistical tests to find which genes have experienced natural selection and which genes have been exchanged.

We found that some gene copies have moved between these populations after they diverged from each other, but these genes were not involved in environmental adaptation. Instead, genes that moved between populations were the ones that had not changed very much since the two populations split. These results are among the first to observe phenomenon in nature.

During the course of this project, we trained three undergraduates from the University of Rochester as well as graduate students from Harvard University and the University of Massachusetts - Boston. The results of our work were presented at the annual meeting of the Society for the Study of Amphibians and Reptiles. Furthermore, we have published one journal article and two natural history notes based on the results of our work. In addition, one article is currently being considered for publication, and we are preparing one more article for submission in the near future.
